a(n) = (-2)^n*Sum_{k=0..n} 2^k*s(n+1,n+1-k), where s(n,k) are the Stirling numbers of the first kind, A048994. - _Mircea Merca_, May 03 2012
G.f.: 1/Q(0), where Q(k)= 1 + x*(4*k+2) - x*(4*k+4)/Q(k+1); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, May 18 2013
G.f.: 2/G(0), where G(k)= 1 + 1/(1 - x*(8*k+4)/(x*(8*k+4) - 1 + 8*x*(k+1)/G(k+1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, May 30 2013
G.f.: G(0)/2, where G(k)= 1 + 1/(1 - 2*x/(2*x + 1/(2*k+1)/G(k+1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jun 01 2013
D-finite with recurrence: a(n) = (4*n-6)*a(n-2) + (4*n-3)*a(n-1), n>=2. - _Ivan N. Ianakiev_, Aug 07 2013
Sum_{n>=0} 1/a(n) = (exp(1/4)*sqrt(Pi)*erf(1/2) + 2)/2 = 1 + A214869, where erf(x) is the error function. - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Nov 10 2016
Sum_{n>=0} (-1)^n/a(n) = 1 - sqrt(Pi)*erfi(1/2)/(2*exp(1/4)), where erfi(x) is the imaginary error function. - _Amiram Eldar_, Feb 20 2021

A001814.name: Coefficient of H_2 when expressing x^{2n} in terms of Hermite polynomials H_m.

A001815.name: a(n) = binomial(n,2) * 2^(n-1).
formula: a(n) = Sum_{i=0..n} i*(n-i)*binomial(n, i). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Nov 11 2004
a(n) = a(1-n) * 2^(2*n-1) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Oct 25 2016
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n-1} Sum_{i=0..n-1} k * binomial(n-1,i). - _Wesley Ivan Hurt_, Sep 20 2017

A001816.name: Coefficients of x^n in Hermite polynomial H_{n+4}

A001817.name: G.f.: Sum_{n>0} x^n/(1-x^(3n)) = Sum_{n>=0} x^(3n+1)/(1-x^(3n+1)).
formula: Moebius transform is period 3 sequence [1, 0, 0, ...]. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 20 2005

A001818.name: Squares of double factorials: (1*3*5*...*(2n-1))^2 = ((2*n-1)!!)^2.
formula: Integral representation as n-th moment of a positive function on a positive halfaxis (solution of the Stieltjes moment problem), in Maple notation:
D-finite with recurrence: a(0) = 1, a(n) = (2*n-1)^2*a(n-1), n > 0.
E.g.f.: 1/sqrt(1-x^2) = Sum_{n >= 0} a(n)*x^(2*n)/(2*n)!. Also arcsin(x) = Sum_{n >= 0} a(n)*x^(2*n+1)/(2*n+1)!. - _Michael Somos_, Jul 03 2002
(-1)^n*a(n) is the coefficient of x^0 in prod(k=1, 2*n, x+2*k-2*n-1). - _Benoit Cloitre_ and _Michael Somos_, Nov 22 2002
G.f.: 1 + x*(G(0) - 1)/(x-1) where G(k) =  1 - (4*k^2+4*k+1)/(1-x/(x - 1/G(k+1) )); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jan 15 2013
a(n) = det(V(i+1,j), 1 <= i,j <= n), where V(n,k) are central factorial numbers of the second kind with odd indices. - _Mircea Merca_, Apr 04 2013
a(n) = (1+x^2)^(n+1/2) * (d/dx)^(2*n) (1+x^2)^(n-1/2).  See Tao link. - _Robert Israel_, Jun 04 2015

A001819.name: Central factorial numbers: second right-hand column of triangle A008955.
formula: Sum_{n>=0} a(n)*x^n/n!^2 = polylog(2, x)/(1-x). - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Jan 23 2003

Recurrence: a(0) = 0, a(1) = 1, a(n+1) = (2*n^2 + 2*n + 1)*a(n) - n^4*a(n-1). The sequence b(n) = n!^2 satisfies the same recurrence with the initial conditions b(0) = 1, b(1) = 1. Hence we obtain the finite continued fraction expansion a(n)/b(n) = 1/(1 - 1^4/(5 - 2^4/(13 - 3^4/(25 - ... -(n-1)^4/((2*n^2 - 2*n + 1)))))), leading to the infinite continued fraction expansion zeta(2) = 1/(1-1^4/(5 - 2^4/(13 - 3^4/(25 - ... - n^4/((2*n^2 + 2*n + 1) - ...))))). Compare with A142995. Compare also with A024167 and A066989. - _Peter Bala_, Jul 18 2008
a(n)/(n!)^2 -> zeta(2) = A013661 as n -> infinity, rewriting the Keane formula. - Najam Haq (njmalhq(AT)yahoo.com), Jan 13 2010
a(n) = s(n+1,2)^2 - 2*s(n+1,1)*s(n+1,3), where s(n,k) are Stirling numbers of the first kind, A048994. - _Mircea Merca_, Apr 03 2012

A001820.name: Central factorial numbers.
formula: a(n) = s(n+3,3)^2 - 2*s(n+3,2)*s(n+3,4) + 2*s(n+3,1)*s(n+3,5), where s(n,k) are Stirling numbers of the first kind, A048994. - _Mircea Merca_, Apr 03 2012
a(n) ~ Pi^5 * n^(2*n+5) / (60 * exp(2*n)). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Feb 23 2015

A001821.name: Central factorial numbers.
formula: a(n) = s(n+4,4)^2 - 2*s(n+4,1)*s(n+4,7) + 2*s(n+4,2)*s(n+4,6) - 2*s(n+4,3)*s(n+4,5), where s(n,k) are Stirling numbers of the first kind, A048994. - _Mircea Merca_, Apr 03 2012
a(n) ~ Pi^7 * n^(2*n+7) / (2520 * exp(2*n)). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Feb 23 2015

A001822.name: Expansion of Sum x^(3n+2)/(1-x^(3n+2)), n=0..inf.
formula: Moebius transform is period 3 sequence [0, 1, 0, ...]. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 20 2005
a(n) + A001817(n) + A000005(n/3) = A000005(n), where A000005(.)=0 if the argument is not an integer. - _R. J. Mathar_, Sep 25 2017

A001823.name: Central factorial numbers: column 2 in triangle A008956.
formula: If we replace n with n-1/2 in this formula we get 16*A000586(n).

A001824.name: Central factorial numbers.
formula: E.g.f.: (arcsin x)^3; that is, a_k is the coefficient of x^(2*k+3) in (arcsin x)^3 multiplied by (2*k+3)! and divided by 6. - Joe Keane (jgk(AT)jgk.org)
(-1)^(n-1)*a(n-1) is the coefficient of x^2 in Product_{k=1..2*n} (x + 2*k - 2*n - 1). - _Benoit Cloitre_ and _Michael Somos_, Nov 22 2002
a(n) = det(V(i+2,j+1), 1 <= i,j <= n), where V(n,k) are central factorial numbers of the second kind with odd indices (A008958). - _Mircea Merca_, Apr 06 2013

A001825.name: Central factorial numbers.
formula: E.g.f.: (arcsin x)^5; that is, a_k is the coefficient of x^(2*k+5) in (arcsin x)^5 multiplied by (2*k+5)! and divided by 5!. - Joe Keane (jgk(AT)jgk.org)
(-1)^(n-2)*a(n-2) is the coefficient of x^4 in prod(k=1, 2*n, x+2*k-2*n-1). - _Benoit Cloitre_ and _Michael Somos_, Nov 22 2002
a(n) = det(V(i+3,j+2), 1 <= i,j <= n), where V(n,k) are central factorial numbers of the second kind with odd indices (A008958). - _Mircea Merca_, Apr 06 2013

A001826.name: Number of divisors of n of form 4k+1.

A001827.name: Related to partially ordered sets.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{p+q+r+s=n} (n!/p!q!r!s!) 2^(pq+qr+rs) where (p,q,r,s) is any nonnegative composition of n. - _Sean A. Irvine_, Sep 24 2015

A001828.name: Related to partially ordered sets.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{p+q+r+s+t=n} (n!/p!q!r!s!t!) 2^(pq+qr+rs+st) where (p,q,r,s,t) is any nonnegative composition of n. - _Sean A. Irvine_, Sep 24 2015

A001829.name: Related to partially ordered sets.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{p+q+r+s+t+u=n} (n!/p!q!r!s!t!u!) 2^(pq+qr+rs+st+tu) where (p,q,r,s,t,u) is any nonnegative composition of n. - _Sean A. Irvine_, Sep 24 2015

A001830.name: Related to partially ordered sets.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{p+q+r+s+t+u+v=n} (n!/p!q!r!s!t!u!v!) 2^(pq+qr+rs+st+tu+uv) where (p,q,r,s,t,u,v) is any nonnegative composition of n. - _Sean A. Irvine_, Sep 24 2015

A001831.name: Number of labeled graded partially ordered sets with n elements of height at most 1.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} binomial(n, k)*(2^k-1)^(n-k). - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Apr 04 2003
E.g.f.: Sum_{n>=0} exp((2^n-1)*x) * x^n/n!. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Nov 27 2007 [correction made by _Paul D. Hanna_, Mar 08 2021]

a(n) ~ c * 2^(n^2/4 + n + 1/2) / sqrt(Pi*n), where c = JacobiTheta3(0,1/2) = EllipticTheta[3, 0, 1/2] = 2.1289368272118771586694585485449... if n is even, and c = JacobiTheta2(0,1/2) = EllipticTheta[2, 0, 1/2] = 2.1289312505130275585916134025753... if n is odd. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Mar 10 2014

A001832.name: Number of labeled connected bipartite graphs on n nodes.
formula: E.g.f.: log(A(x))/2 where A(x) is e.g.f. of A047863.
a(n) = A002031(n)/2, for n > 1. - _Geoffrey Critzer_, May 10 2011

A001833.name: Number of labeled graded partially ordered sets with n elements.

A001834.name: a(0) = 1, a(1) = 5, a(n) = 4*a(n-1) - a(n-2).
formula: G.f.: (1 + x)/((1 - 4*x + x^2)). _Simon Plouffe_ in his 1992 dissertation.
a(n) = S(2*n, sqrt(6)) = S(n, 4) + S(n-1, 4); S(n, x) := U(n, x/2), Chebyshev polynomials of 2nd kind, A049310. S(n, 4) = A001353(n).
For all members x of the sequence, 3*x^2 + 6 is a square. Lim_{n->infinity} a(n)/a(n-1) = 2 + sqrt(3). - _Gregory V. Richardson_, Oct 10 2002
Let q(n, x) = Sum_{i=0..n} x^(n - i)*binomial(2*n - i, i); then (-1)^n*q(n, -6) = a(n). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Nov 10 2002
a(n) = 2^(-n)*Sum_{k>=0} binomial(2*n + 1, 2*k)*3^k; see A091042. - _Philippe Deléham_, Mar 01 2004

a(n+1) - 2*a(n) = 3*A001835(n+1). Using the known relation A001835(n+1) = sqrt((a(n)^2 + 2)/3) it follows that a(n+1) - 2*a(n) = sqrt(3*(a(n)^2 + 2)). Therefore a(n+1)^2 + a(n)^2 - 4*a(n+1)*a(n) - 6 = 0. - _Creighton Dement_, Apr 18 2005
Equals binomial transform of A026150 starting (1, 4, 10, 28, 76, ...) and double binomial transform of (1, 3, 3, 9, 9, 27, 27, 81, 81, ...). - _Gary W. Adamson_, Nov 30 2007
Sequence satisfies 6 = f(a(n), a(n+1)) where f(u, v) = u^2 + v^2 - 4*u*v. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 19 2008
a(n) = A061278(n+1) - A061278(n-1) for n>=2. - _John P. McSorley_, Jun 20 2020

A001835.name: a(n) = 4*a(n-1) - a(n-2), with a(0) = 1, a(1) = 1.
formula: G.f.: (1 - 3*x)/(1 - 4*x + x^2). -  _Simon Plouffe_ in his 1992 dissertation
a(n+1) = Sum_{k=0..n} (2^k * binomial(n + k, n - k), n >= 0. - _Len Smiley_, Dec 09 2001
Lim_{n->infinity} a(n)/a(n-1) = 2 + sqrt(3). - _Gregory V. Richardson_, Oct 10 2002
a(n) = 2*A061278(n-1) + 1 for n > 0. - Bruce Corrigan (scentman(AT)myfamily.com), Nov 04 2002
Let q(n, x) = Sum_{i=0..n} x^(n-i)*binomial(2*n - i, i); then q(n, 2) = a(n+1). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Nov 10 2002

a(n+1) = Sum_{k=0..n} ((-1)^k)*((2*n+1)/(2*n + 1 - k))*binomial(2*n + 1 - k, k)*6^(n - k) (from standard T(n,x)/x, n >= 1, Chebyshev sum formula). The Smiley and Cloitre sum representation is that of the S(2*n, i*sqrt(2))*(-1)^n Chebyshev polynomial. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Nov 29 2002

a(n) = S(n-1, 4) - S(n-2, 4) = T(2*n-1, sqrt(3/2))/sqrt(3/2) = S(2*(n-1), i*sqrt(2))*(-1)^(n - 1), with S(n, x) := U(n, x/2), resp. T(n, x), Chebyshev's polynomials of the second, resp. first, kind. See A049310 and A053120. S(-1, x) = 0, S(-2, x) = -1, S(n, 4) = A001353(n+1), T(-1, x) = x.
Sequence satisfies -2 = f(a(n), a(n+1)) where f(u, v) = u^2 + v^2 - 4*u*v. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 19 2008

a(n) = (1/6)*(3*(2 - sqrt(3))^n + sqrt(3)*(2 - sqrt(3))^n + 3*(2 + sqrt(3))^n - sqrt(3)*(2 + sqrt(3))^n) (Mathematica's solution to the recurrence relation). - Sarah-Marie Belcastro (smbelcas(AT)toroidalsnark.net), Jul 04 2009

If p[1] = 3, p[i] = 2, (i > 1), and if A is Hessenberg matrix of order n defined by: A[i,j] = p[j-i+1], (i <= j), A[i,j] = -1, (i = j+1), and A[i,j] = 0 otherwise. Then, for n >= 1, a(n+1) = det A. - _Milan Janjic_, Apr 29 2010

A001836.name: Numbers n such that phi(2n-1) < phi(2n), where phi is Euler's totient function A000010.

A001837.name: Numbers n such that phi(2n+1) < phi(2n).

A001838.name: Numbers n such that phi(n+2) = phi(n) + 2.

A001839.name: The coding-theoretic function A(n,4,3).
formula: Known exactly for all n - see Theorem 4 of Brouwer et al. (1990): A(n, 4, 3) = floor((n/3)*floor((n-1)/2))-1 if n is congruent to 5 (mod 6) and A(n, 4, 3) = floor((n/3)*floor((n-1)/2)) if n is not congruent to 5 (mod 6). - Shelly Jones (shellysalt(AT)yahoo.com), Apr 27 2004
a(n) = a(n-1) + a(n-2) - a(n-3) + a(n-6) - a(n-7) - a(n-8) + a(n-9). - _Eric W. Weisstein_, Jul 13 2017

A001840.name: Expansion of x /((1 - x)^2 * (1 - x^3)).
formula: a(n+1) = a(n) + A008620(n) = A002264(n+3). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Aug 01 2002
a(n) = binomial(n+3, 3)/(n+3) + cos(2*Pi*(n-1)/3)/9 + sqrt(3)sin(2*Pi*(n-1)/3)/9 - 1/9. - _Paul Barry_, Jan 01 2005
G.f.: x/(1 + x + x^2)/(1 - x)^3. - Maksym Voznyy (voznyy(AT)mail.ru), Jul 27 2009
Empirical: a(n) = floor((n+3)/(e^(6/(n+3))-1)). - _Richard R. Forberg_, Jul 24 2013

A001842.name: Expansion of Sum_{n>=0} x^(4*n+3)/(1 - x^(4*n+3)).
formula: G.f.: Sum_{k>=1} x^(3*k)/(1 - x^(4*k)). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Sep 11 2019

A001843.name: The coding-theoretic function A(n,4,4).
formula: See Theorem 1.2 of Bao and Ji, 2015 (Theorem 4.9 in the arXiv preprint).

A001844.name: Centered square numbers: a(n) = 2*n*(n+1)+1. Sums of two consecutive squares. Also, consider all Pythagorean triples (X, Y, Z=Y+1) ordered by increasing Z; then sequence gives Z values.
formula: a(n) = 1/real(z(n+1)) where z(1)=i, (i^2=-1), z(k+1) = 1/(z(k)+2i). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Aug 06 2002
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n+1} (-1)^k*binomial(n, k)*Sum_{j=0..n-k+1} binomial(n-k+1, j)*j^2. - _Paul Barry_, Dec 22 2004
a(n) = A000217(2n+1) - n. - _Ivan N. Ianakiev_, Nov 08 2013

A001845.name: Centered octahedral numbers (crystal ball sequence for cubic lattice).
formula: G.f.: (1+x)^3 /(1-x)^4. [conjectured (correctly) by _Simon Plouffe_ in his 1992 dissertation]
First differences of A014820(n). - _Alexander Adamchuk_, May 23 2006
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..min(3,n)} 2^k * binomial(3,k) * binomial(n,k). See Bump et al. - _Tom Copeland_, Sep 05 2014
a(n) = A002412(n+1) + A016061(n-1) for n > 0. - _Bruce J. Nicholson_, Nov 12 2017

A001846.name: Centered 4-dimensional orthoplex numbers (crystal ball sequence for 4-dimensional cubic lattice).
formula: a(n) = (2*n^4+4*n^3+10*n^2+8*n+3)/3. - S. Bujnowski & B. Dubalski (slawb(AT)atr.bydgoszcz.pl), Mar 07 2002
a(n) = sum(k=0..min(4,n), 2^k * binomial(4,k)* binomial(n,k) ). See Bump et al. - _Tom Copeland_, Sep 05 2014

A001847.name: Crystal ball sequence for 5-dimensional cubic lattice.
formula: a(n) = (4*n^5+10*n^4+40*n^3+50*n^2+46*n+15)/15. - S. Bujnowski & B. Dubalski (slawb(AT)atr.bydgoszcz.pl), Mar 07 2002
a(n) = sum(k=0..min(5,n), 2^k * binomial(5,k)* binomial(n,k) ). See Bump et al. - _Tom Copeland_, Sep 05 2014

A001848.name: Crystal ball sequence for 6-dimensional cubic lattice.
formula: a(n) = 4/45*n^6+4/15*n^5+14/9*n^4+8/3*n^3+196/45*n^2+46/15*n+1. - S. Bujnowski & B. Dubalski (slawb(AT)atr.bydgoszcz.pl), Nov 25 2002
a(n)= sum(k=0..min(6,n), 2^k * binomial(6,k)* binomial(n,k) ). See Bump et al. - _Tom Copeland_, Sep 05 2014

A001849.name: Crystal ball sequence for 7-dimensional cubic lattice.

A001850.name: Central Delannoy numbers: a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} C(n,k)*C(n+k,k).
formula: a(n) = P_n(3), where P_n is n-th Legendre polynomial.
a(n) = a(n-1) + 2*A002002(n) = Sum_{j} A063007(n, j). - _Henry Bottomley_, Jul 02 2001
Dominant term in asymptotic expansion is binomial(2*n, n)/2^(1/4)*((sqrt(2) + 1)/2)^(2*n + 1)*(1 + c_1/n + c_2/n^2 + ...). - _Michael David Hirschhorn_
a(n) = Sum_{i=0..n} (A000079(i)*A008459(n, i)) = Sum_{i=0..n} (2^i * C(n, i)^2). - Antti Karttunen, Oct 10 2001
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} C(n+k, n-k)*C(2*k, k). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Feb 13 2003
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} C(n, k)^2 * 2^k. - _Michael Somos_, Oct 08 2003
a(n - 1) = coefficient of x^n in A120588(x)^n if n>=0. - _Michael Somos_, Apr 11 2012

INVERT transform is A109980. BINOMIAL transform is A080609. BINOMIAL transform of A006139. PSUM transform is A089165. PSUMSIGN transform is A026933. First backward difference is A110170. - _Michael Somos_, May 11 2012
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} C(2*n-k, n)*C(n, k). - _Paul Barry_, Apr 23 2005
a(n) = Sum_{k>=n} binomial(k, n)^2/2^(k+1). - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Aug 25 2006
a(n) = a(-1 - n) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 23 2006
D-finite with recurrence: a(-1) = a(0) = 1; n*a(n) = 3*(2*n-1)*a(n-1) - (n-1)*a(n-2). Eq (4) in _T. D. Noe_'s article in JIS 9 (2006) #06.2.7.

Define general Delannoy numbers by (i,j > 0): d(i,0) = d(0,j) = 1 =: d(0,0) and d(i,j) = d(i-1,j-1) + d(i-2,j-1) + d(i-1,j). Then a(k) = Sum_{j >= 0} d(k,j)^2 + d(k-1,j)^2. This is a special case of the following formula for general Delannoy numbers: d(k,j) = Sum_{i >= 0, p=0..n} d(p, i) * d(n-p, j-i) + d(p-1, i) * d(n-p-1, j-i-1). - _Peter E John_, Oct 19 2006
Coefficient of x^n in (1 + 3*x + 2*x^2)^n. - _N-E. Fahssi_, Jan 11 2008
G.f.: 1/(1 - x - 2*x/(1 - x - x/(1 - x - x/(1 - x - x/(1 - ... (continued fraction). - _Paul Barry_, May 28 2009
G.f.: d/dx log(1/(1 - x*A001003(x))). - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Apr 19 2011
G.f.: 1/(2*Q(0) + x - 1) where Q(k) = 1 + k*(1-x) - x - x*(k + 1)*(k + 2)/Q(k+1); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Mar 14 2013
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} C(n,k) * C(n+k,k). - _Joerg Arndt_, May 11 2013
G.f.: 2/G(0), where G(k) = 1 + 1/(1 - x*(6 - x)*(2*k - 1)/(x*(6 - x)*(2*k - 1) + 2*(k + 1)/G(k+1) )); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jul 16 2013
G.f.: G(0)/2, where G(k) = 1 + 1/(1 - x*(6 - x)*(2*k + 1)/(x*(6 - x)*(2*k + 1) + 2*(k + 1)/G(k+1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jul 17 2013
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n/2} C(n-k,k) * 3^(n-2*k) * 2^k * C(n,k). - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Jun 29 2015
a(n) = Sum_{0 <= j, k <= n} (-1)^(n+j)*C(n,k)*C(n,j)*C(n+k,k)*C(n+k+j,k+j). Cf. A126086 and A274668. - _Peter Bala_, Jan 15 2020
a(n) ~ c * (3 + 2*sqrt(2))^n / sqrt(n), where c = 1/sqrt(4*Pi*(3*sqrt(2)-4)) = 0.572681... (Banderier and Schwer, 2005). - _Amiram Eldar_, Jun 07 2020

A001851.name: Total diameter of unlabeled trees with n nodes.

A001852.name: Total diameter of labeled trees with n nodes.

A001853.name: Total height of trees with n nodes.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n-1} A034781(n,k)*k. - _Sean A. Irvine_, Mar 24 2016

A001854.name: Total height of all rooted trees on n labeled nodes.
formula: A000435(n)/a(n) ~ 1/2 (see A000435 and the Renyi-Szekeres result mentioned in the Comments). - David desJardins, Jan 20 2017

A001855.name: Sorting numbers: maximal number of comparisons for sorting n elements by binary insertion.
formula: G.f.: x/(1-x)^2 * Sum_{k>=0} x^2^k. - _Ralf Stephan_, Apr 13 2002
a(1)=0, for n>1, a(n) = ceiling(n*a(n-1)/(n-1)+1). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Apr 26 2003
a(n) = n-1 + min { a(k)+a(n-k) : 1 <= k <= n-1 }, cf. A003314. - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Aug 15 2004
a(n) = A061168(n-1) + n - 1 for n>1. - _Hieronymus Fischer_, Dec 05 2006

A001856.name: A self-generating sequence: every positive integer occurs as a(i)-a(j) for a unique pair i,j.
formula: a(1)=1, a(2)=2, a(2n+1) = 2a(2n), a(2n+2) = a(2n+1) + r(n), where r(n) = smallest positive number not of form a(j) - a(i) with 1 <= i < j <= 2n+1.

A001857.name: a(1)=2, a(2)=3; for n >= 3, a(n) is smallest number that is uniquely of the form a(j) + a(k) with 1 <= j < k < n.

A001858.name: Number of forests of trees on n labeled nodes.
formula: E.g.f.: exp( Sum_{n>=1} n^(n-2)*x^n/n! ). This implies (by a theorem of Wright) that a(n) ~ exp(1/2)*n^(n-2). - _N. J. A. Sloane_, May 12 2008 [Corrected by Philippe Flajolet, Aug 17 2008]
E.g.f.: exp(T - T^2/2), where T = T(x) = Sum_{ n>=1} n^(n-1)*x^n/n! is Euler's tree function (see A000169). - _Len Smiley_, Dec 12 2001
Shifts 1 place left under the hyperbinomial transform (cf. A088956). - _Paul D. Hanna_, Nov 03 2003

A001859.name: Triangular numbers plus quarter-squares: n*(n+1)/2 + floor((n+1)^2/4) (i.e., A000217(n) + A002620(n+1)).
formula: a(n) = A006578(-1-n) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, May 10 2006
Starting (2, 5, 10, 16, 24, ...), = binomial transform of [2, 3, 2, -1, 2, -4, 8, -16, 32, ...]. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Nov 30 2007
a(2*n) = A045944(n), a(2*n - 1) = A049450(n) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Nov 03 2014
0 = -6 + a(n) - 2*a(n+2) + a(n+4) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Nov 03 2014
0 = a(n)*(+a(n+1) - a(n+2)) + a(n+1)*(-3 - a(n+1) + a(n+2)) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Nov 03 2014
a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n} floor((n+k+2)/2). - _Wesley Ivan Hurt_, Mar 31 2017

A001860.name: Number of series-reduced planted trees with n+9 nodes and 4 internal nodes.

A001861.name: Expansion of e.g.f. exp(2*(exp(x) - 1)).
formula: G.f. satisfies 2*(x/(1-x))*A(x/(1-x)) = A(x) - 1; twice the binomial transform equals the sequence shifted one place left. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Dec 08 2003
PE = exp(matpascal(5)-matid(6)); A = PE^2; a(n)=A[n,1]. - _Gottfried Helms_, Apr 08 2007
O.g.f.: Sum_{n>=0} 2^n*x^n / Product_{k=1..n} (1-k*x). - _Paul D. Hanna_, Feb 15 2012
G.f.: (G(0) - 1)/(x-1)/2 where G(k) =  1 - 2/(1-k*x)/(1-x/(x-1/G(k+1) )); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jan 16 2013
G.f.: 1/Q(0) where Q(k) =  1 + x*k - x - x/(1 - 2*x*(k+1)/Q(k+1) ); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Mar 07 2013
G.f.: ((1+x)/Q(0)-1)/(2*x), where Q(k)= 1 - (k+1)*x - 2*(k+1)*x^2/Q(k+1); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, May 03 2013
G.f.: T(0)/(1-2*x), where T(k) = 1 - 2*x^2*(k+1)/( 2*x^2*(k+1) - (1-2*x-x*k)*(1-3*x-x*k)/T(k+1) ); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Oct 24 2013
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} A033306(n,k) = Sum_{k=0..n} binomial(n,k)*Bell(k)*Bell(n-k), where Bell = A000110 (see Motzkin, p. 170). - _Danny Rorabaugh_, Oct 18 2015
a(0) = 1 and a(n) = 2 * Sum_{k=0..n-1} binomial(n-1,k)*a(k) for n > 0. - _Seiichi Manyama_, Sep 25 2017 [corrected by _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Jul 12 2020]

A001862.name: Number of forests of least height with n nodes.

A001863.name: Normalized total height of rooted trees with n nodes.

A001864.name: Total height of rooted trees with n labeled nodes.
formula: a(n) = sum(k=1, n-1, binomial(n, k)*(n-k)^(n-k)*k^k). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Mar 22 2003

A001865.name: Number of connected functions on n labeled nodes.
formula: Integral representation in terms of incomplete Gamma function: a(n)=exp(n+1)*Integral_{x=n+1..infinity} x^n exp(-x) dx.
Asymptotics: sqrt(Pi*n/2)*n^(n-1) - _N-E. Fahssi_, Jan 25 2008, corrected by _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Nov 27 2012
a(n) = (1/n) * Sum_{k=1..n} C(n,k) * (n-k)^(n-k) * k^k. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Jul 04 2013
Note that (n-1)!*( e^n - Sum_{k >= 0} k^3*n^(n + k - 1)/(n + k)!) ) also appears to be an integer sequence beginning [1, 5, 37, 370, 4681, 71736, 1292005, ...]. (End)

A001866.name: Number of connected graphs with n nodes and n edges.
formula: Explicit formula: a(n)=(n!^2*n^(n-1)/2)*Sum{k=2,...,n}n^(-k)/(n-k)!; Recursion: a(2)=1, for n>=3, a(n)=n!*((n-1)!/2+Sum{k=2,...,n-1}(-1)^(n+k+1)*k^(n-k)*C(n,k)a(k)/k! [_Vladimir Shevelev_, Mar 25 2010]

A001867.name: Number of n-bead necklaces with 3 colors.

A001868.name: Number of n-bead necklaces with 4 colors.

A001869.name: Number of n-bead necklaces with 5 colors.

A001870.name: Expansion of (1-x)/(1 - 3*x + x^2)^2.
formula: a(n) = ((2*n-1)*Fibonacci(2*n) - n*Fibonacci(2*n-1))/5 [Czabarka et al.]. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Sep 18 2018

A001871.name: Expansion of 1/(1 - 3*x + x^2)^2.
formula: a(n) = (2*a(n-1) + (n+1)*F(2n+4))/3, where F(n) = A000045 (Fibonacci numbers). - _Emeric Deutsch_, Oct 08 2002
a(n) = (Sum_{k=0..n} S(k, 3)S(n-k, 3)) S(n, x) = U(n, x/2) Chebyshev polynomials of 2nd kind, A049310. - _Paul Barry_, Nov 14 2003
a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n+1} F(2k)*F(2(n-k+2)) where F(k) is the k-th Fibonacci number. - Dan Daly (ddaly(AT)du.edu), Apr 24 2008

A001872.name: Convolved Fibonacci numbers.
formula: For n > 3, a(n-3) = Sum_{h+i+j+k=n} F(h)*F(i)*F(j)*F(k). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Nov 01 2002
a(n) = F'''(n+3, 1)/6, i.e., 1/6 times the 3rd derivative of the (n+3)th Fibonacci polynomial evaluated at 1. - _T. D. Noe_, Jan 18 2006

a(n) = (((-i)^n)/3!)*(d^3/dx^3)S(n+3,x)|_{x=i}, where i is the imaginary unit. Third derivative of Chebyshev S(n+3,x) polynomial evaluated at x=i multiplied by ((-i)^(n-3))/3!. See A049310 for the S-polynomials. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Apr 04 2007

A001873.name: Convolved Fibonacci numbers.
formula: a(n) = F''''(n+4, 1)/24, i.e., 1/24 times the 4th derivative of the (n+4)th Fibonacci polynomial evaluated at 1. - _T. D. Noe_, Jan 18 2006

A001874.name: Convolved Fibonacci numbers.
formula: a(n) = F'''''(n+5, 1)/5!, i.e., 1/5! times the 5th derivative of the (n+5)th Fibonacci polynomial evaluated at 1. - _T. D. Noe_, Jan 18 2006

A001875.name: Convolved Fibonacci numbers.
formula: a(n) = F''''''(n+6, 1)/6!, i.e., 1/6! times the 6th derivative of the (n+6)th Fibonacci polynomial evaluated at 1. - _T. D. Noe_, Jan 18 2006

A001876.name: Number of divisors of n of form 5k+1; a(0)=0.

A001877.name: Number of divisors of n of form 5k+2; a(0) = 0.

A001878.name: Number of divisors of n of form 5k+3; a(0) = 0.
formula: G.f.: Sum_{k>=1} x^(3*k)/(1 - x^(5*k)). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Sep 11 2019

A001879.name: a(n) = (2n+2)!/(n!2^(n+1)).
formula: D-finite with recurrence a(n) = 6*a(n-1) + ((2*n-1)^2)*a(n-2), a(-1)=0, a(0)=1. (End)
With interpolated 0's, e.g.f.: B(A(x)) where B(x)= x exp(x) and A(x)=x^2/2.
G.f.: - G(0)/2 where G(k) =  1 - (2*k+3)/(1 - x/(x - (k+1)/G(k+1) )); (recursively defined continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Dec 06 2012
G.f.: (1-x)/(2*x^2*Q(0)) - 1/(2*x^2), where Q(k)= 1 - x*(k+1)/Q(k+1)); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, May 20 2013
Integral representation as n-th moment of a signed function w(x) of bounded variation on (0,infinity),
For x>1, w(x)>0. w(0)=w(1)=limit(w(x),x=infinity)=0. For x<1, w(x)<0.

A001880.name: Coefficients of Bessel polynomials y_n (x).
formula: (n-4)*a(n) = (n-2)*(2*n-5)*a(n-1) for n = 5, 6, .. , with a(4) = 1. - _Johannes W. Meijer_, May 24 2009

A001881.name: Coefficients of Bessel polynomials y_n (x).
formula: E.g.f.: x*(1 + 3*x/2)/(1 - 2*x)^(9/2), with offset 1. - _G. C. Greubel_, Aug 13 2017
G.f.: t^5 * hypergeometric2F0(3, 7/2; -; 2*t) = t^5 + 21*t^6 + .... - _G. C. Greubel_, Aug 16 2017

A001883.name: Number of permutations s of {1,2,...,n} such that |s(i)-i|>1 for each i=1,2,...,n.
formula: a(n) = (n+1)*a(n-1) - (n-3)*a(n-2) - (n-4)*a(n-3) + (n-4)*a(n-4) + a(n-5) + (-1)^n * Lucas(n-3), n > 4. [Riordan] (Note: There is a slight mistake in Riordan's paper. On p. 3 it should say that a_5 = 3.) - _Eric M. Schmidt_, Oct 09 2017

A001887.name: Number of permutations p of {1,2,...,n} such that p(i) - i < 0 or p(i) - i > 2 for all i.

A001891.name: Hit polynomials; convolution of natural numbers with Fibonacci numbers F(2), F(3), F(4),....
formula: G.f.: x*(1+x)/((1-x-x^2)*(1-x)^2). - _Simon Plouffe_ in his 1992 dissertation
a(n) = a(n-1) + a(n-2) + (2n+1); a(-x)=0. - _Barry E. Williams_, Mar 27 2000
a(n) = 3*a(n-1) - 2*a(n-2) - a(n-3) + a(n-4). - Sam Lachterman (slachterman(AT)fuse.net), Sep 22 2003

A001892.name: Number of permutations of (1,...,n) having n-2 inversions (n>=2).
formula: a(n) = 2^(2*n-3)/sqrt(Pi*n)*Q*(1+O(n^{-1})), where Q is a digital search tree constant, Q = 0.288788095... (see A048651). - corrected by _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Mar 16 2014

A001893.name: Number of permutations of (1,...,n) having n-3 inversions (n>=3).
formula: a(n) = 2^(2*n-4)/sqrt(Pi*n)*Q*(1+O(n^{-1})), where Q is a digital search tree constant, Q = 0.2887880951... (see A048651). - corrected by _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Mar 16 2014

A001894.name: Number of permutations of {1,...,n} having n-4 inversions (n>=4).
formula: a(n) = 2^(2*n-5)/sqrt(Pi*n)*Q*(1+O(n^{-1})), where Q is a digital search tree constant, Q = 0.2887880951... (see A048651). - corrected by _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Mar 16 2014

A001895.name: Number of rooted planar 2-trees with n nodes.

A001896.name: Numerators of cosecant numbers {-2*(2^(2*n-1)-1)*Bernoulli(2*n)}; also of Bernoulli(2n,1/2) and Bernoulli(2n,1/4).
formula: See A062715 for a method of obtaining the cosecant numbers from the square of Pascal's triangle. - _Peter Bala_, Jul 18 2013

A001897.name: Denominators of cosecant numbers: -2*(2^(2*n-1)-1)*Bernoulli(2*n).
formula: a(n) = denominator((2*n)!*Li_{2*n}(1)) for n > 0. - _Peter Luschny_, Jun 29 2012
a(n) = denominator(r(n)) where r(n) = Sum_{0..n} (-1)^(n-k)*A241171(n, k)/(2*k+1).
Apparently a(n) = denominator(Sum_{k=0..2*n-2} (-1)^k*E2(2*n-1, k+1)/binomial(4*n-1, k+1)), where E2(n, k) denotes the second-order Eulerian numbers A340556. - _Peter Luschny_, Feb 17 2021

A001898.name: Denominators of Bernoulli polynomials B(n)(x).
formula: These Bernoulli polynomials B(s) = B(s)(x) are defined by: B(0) = 1; B(s) = (-x/s)*Sum_{t=1..s} (-1)^t*binomial(s, t)*Bernoulli(t)*B(s-t), where Bernoulli(t) are the usual Bernoulli numbers A027641/A027642. Also B(s)(1) = Bernoulli(s).

A001899.name: Number of divisors of n of form 5k+4; a(0) = 0.
formula: G.f.: Sum_{k>=1} x^(4*k)/(1 - x^(5*k)). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Sep 11 2019

A001900.name: Successive numerators of Wallis's approximation to Pi/2 (unreduced).
formula: Conjecture: a(n) - a(n-1) - n*(n-1)*a(n-2) = 0. - _R. J. Mathar_, Jun 07 2013 [The proof, for n >= 2, follows from the bisection recurrence given below. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Dec 07 2017]
E.g.f.: E(0), where E(k)= 1 + 2*x*(k+1)/((2*k+1) - x*(2*k+1)/(x + 1/E(k+1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jun 08 2013
G.f.: G(0), where G(k)= 1 + 2*x*(k+1)/(1 - 2*x*(k+1)/(2*x*(k+1) + 1/G(k+1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jun 08 2013

Bisection: a(2*k+1) = ((2*k+1)+1)*a(2*k), a(2*k) = 2*k*a(2*k-1), k >= 0, with a(0) = 1. The proof is obvious from the numbers in the numerator (see the row N in the example). From a proposal by _David James Sycamore_, Nov 02 2017 based on the fractions 4/1, 8/3, 32/9, 128/45, ... converging very slowly to Pi, given on p. 16 of the Derbyshire link. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Dec 06 2017

A001901.name: Successive numerators of Wallis's approximation to Pi/2 (reduced).
formula: 1/1 * 2/1 * 2/3 * 4/3 * 4/5 * 6/5 * 6/7 * ...; partial products (reduced). Here the numerators with offset 0.
a(n) = numerator(W(n)), for n >= 0, with W(n) = Product_{k=0..n} N(k)/D(k) (reduced), with N(k) = 2*floor((k+1)/2) for k >= 1 and N(0) = 1, and D(k) = 2*floor(k/2) + 1, for k >= 0. (End)

A001902.name: Successive denominators of Wallis's approximation to Pi/2 (reduced).
formula: 1/1 * 2/1 * 2/3 * 4/3 * 4/5 * 6/5 * 6/7 * ...; partial products (reduced). Here the denominators with offset 0.
a(n) = denominator(W(n)), for n >= 0, with W(n) = Product_{k=0..n} N(k)/D(k) (reduced), with N(k) = 2*floor((k+1)/2) for k >= 1 and N(0) = 1, and D(k) = 2*floor(k/2) + 1, for k >= 0. (End)

A001903.name: Final digit of 7^n.
formula: a(n) = 10 - a(n-2) for n > 1. - _Vincenzo Librandi_, Feb 08 2011

A001904.name: From higher order Bernoulli numbers: absolute value of numerator of D Number D2n(2n).
formula: E.g.f. for D-Noerlund numbers: (x/log(x+sqrt(1+x^2)))/sqrt(1+x^2). - Herman Jamke (hermanjamke(AT)fastmail.fm), Jul 26 2010

A001905.name: From higher-order Bernoulli numbers: absolute value of numerator of D-number D2n(2n-1).

A001906.name: F(2n) = bisection of Fibonacci sequence: a(n) = 3*a(n-1) - a(n-2).
formula: G.f.: x / (1 - 3*x + x^2). -  _Simon Plouffe_ in his 1992 dissertation
Invert transform of natural numbers: a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n} k*a(n-k), a(0) = 1. - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Apr 27 2001
a(n) = S(n-1, 3) with S(n, x) = U(n, x/2) Chebyshev's polynomials of the 2nd kind, see A049310.
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} binomial(n, k)*F(k). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Sep 03 2002
Lim_{n->infinity} a(n)/a(n-1) = 1 + phi = (3 + sqrt(5))/2. This sequence includes all of the elements of A033888 combined with A033890.
a(n) = n + Sum_{k=0..n-1} Sum_{i=0..k} a(i) = n + A054452(n). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Jan 26 2003
a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n} binomial(n+k-1, n-k). - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Mar 23 2003
Second diagonal of array defined by T(i, 1) = T(1, j) = 1, T(i, j) = Max(T(i-1, j) + T(i-1, j-1); T(i-1, j-1) + T(i, j-1)). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Aug 05 2003
F(2n+2) = 1, 3, 8, ... is the binomial transform of F(n+2). - _Paul Barry_, Apr 24 2004
Partial sums of A001519(n). - _Lekraj Beedassy_, Jun 11 2004
a(n) = Sum_{i=0..n-1} binomial(2*n-1-i, i)*5^(n-i-1)*(-1)^i. - Mario Catalani (mario.catalani(AT)unito.it), Jul 23 2004
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} binomial(n+k, n-k-1) = Sum_{k=0..n} binomial(n+k, 2k+1).
a(n+1) = Sum_{k=0..floor(n/2)} binomial(n-k, k)*(-1)^k*3^(n-2*k). - _Paul Barry_, Oct 25 2004
The i-th term of the sequence is the entry (1, 2) in the i-th power of the 2 X 2 matrix M = ((1, 1), (1, 2)). - _Simone Severini_, Oct 15 2005

Computation suggests that this sequence is the Hankel transform of A005807. The Hankel transform of {a(n)} is Det[{{a(1), ..., a(n)}, {a(2), ..., a(n+1)}, ..., {a(n), ..., a(2n-1)}}]. - _John W. Layman_, Jul 21 2000
a(n+1) = Sum_{i=0..n} Sum_{j=0..n} binomial(n-i, j)*binomial(n-j, i). - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Feb 20 2005
a(n) = (2/sqrt(5))*sinh(2*n*psi), where psi:=log(phi) and phi=(1+sqrt(5))/2. - _Hieronymus Fischer_, Apr 24 2007
a(n) = ((phi+1)^n - A001519(n))/phi with phi=(1+sqrt(5))/2. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Nov 22 2007
Row sums of triangle A135871. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Dec 02 2007

a(n)^2 = Sum_{k=1..n} a(2*k-1). This is a property of any sequence S(n) such that S(n) = B*S(n-1) - S(n-2) with S(0) = 0 and S(1) = 1 including {0,1,2,3,...} where B = 2. - _Kenneth J Ramsey_, Mar 23 2008
a(n) = 1/sqrt(5)*(phi^(2*n+2) - phi^(-2*n-2)), where phi = (1+sqrt(5))/2, the golden ratio. - _Udita Katugampola_ (SIU), Sep 24 2008

If p[i] = i and if A is Hessenberg matrix of order n defined by: A[i,j] = p[j-i+1], (i<=j), A[i,j] = -1, (i = j+1), and A[i,j] = 0 otherwise. Then, for n >= 1, a(n) = det(A). - _Milan Janjic_, May 02 2010

If p[i] = Stirling2(i,2) and if A is the Hessenberg matrix of order n defined by: A[i,j] = p[j-i+1], (i<=j), A[i,j] = -1, (i = j+1), and A[i,j] = 0 otherwise. Then, for n >= 1, a(n-1) = det(A). - _Milan Janjic_, May 08 2010
a(n) = 1 + a(n-1) + Sum_{i=1..n-1} a(i), with a(0)=0. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Feb 19 2011

a(n) is equal to the permanent of the (n-1) X (n-1) Hessenberg matrix with 3's along the main diagonal, i's along the superdiagonal and the subdiagonal (i is the imaginary unit), and 0's everywhere else. - _John M. Campbell_, Jun 09 2011
a(n), n > 1 is equal to the determinant of an (n-x) X (n-1) tridiagonal matrix with 3's in the main diagonal, 1's in the super and subdiagonals, and the rest 0's. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Jun 27 2011
a(n) = b such that Integral_{x=0..Pi/2} sin(n*x)/(3/2-cos(x)) dx = c + b*log(3). - _Francesco Daddi_, Aug 01 2011

G.f.: A(x) = x/(1-3*x+x^2) = G(0)/sqrt(5); where G(k)= 1 -(a^k)/(1 - b*x/(b*x - 2*(a^k)/G(k+1))), a = (7-3*sqrt(5))/2, b = 3+sqrt(5), if |x|<(3-sqrt(5))/2 = 0.3819660...; (continued fraction 3 kind, 3-step ). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jun 25 2012
G.f.: x/(1-2*x) + x^2/(1-2*x)/(Q(0)-x) where Q(k) = 1 - x/(x*k+1)/Q(k+1); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Feb 23 2013
G.f.: G(0)/2 - 1, where G(k)= 1 + 1/( 1 - x/(x + (1-x)^2/G(k+1) )); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jul 16 2013
G.f.: x*G(0)/(2-3*x), where G(k)= 1 + 1/( 1 - x*(5*k-9)/(x*(5*k-4) - 6/G(k+1) )); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jul 17 2013
Sum_{n>=1} 1/(a(n) + 1/a(n)) = 1. Compare with A001519, A049660 and A049670. - _Peter Bala_, Nov 29 2013
a(n) = U(n-1,3/2) where U(n-1,x) is Chebyshev polynomial of the second kind. - _Milan Janjic_, Jan 25 2015
The o.g.f. A(x) satisfies A(x) + A(-x) + 6*A(x)*A(-x) = 0. The o.g.f. for A004187 equals -A(sqrt(x))*A(-sqrt(x)). - _Peter Bala_, Apr 02 2015

For n > 3, a(n) = floor(MA) - 4 for n even and floor(MA) + 5 for n odd.  MA is the maximum area of a quadrilateral with lengths of sides in order L(n), L(n), F(n-3), F(n+3), with L(n)=A000032(n). The ratio of the longer diagonal to the shorter approaches 5/3. - _J. M. Bergot_, Feb 16 2016
a(n+1) = Sum_{j=0..n} Sum_{k=0..j} binomial(n-j,k)*binomial(j,k)*2^(j-k). - _Tony Foster III_, Sep 18 2017
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n-1} Sum_{i=0..n-1} C(k+i,k-i). - _Wesley Ivan Hurt_, Sep 21 2017
a(n) = Sum_{k=1..A000041(n)} A305309(n, k), n >= 1. Also row sums of triangle A078812.- _Wolfdieter Lang_, May 31 2018
a(n) = H(2*n, 1, 1/2) for n > 0 where H(n, a, b) -> hypergeom([a - n/2, b - n/2], [1 - n], -4). - _Peter Luschny_, Sep 03 2019

A001907.name: Expansion of e.g.f. exp(-x)/(1-4*x).
formula: E.g.f. A(x) = exp(-x)/(1-4x) satisfies (1-4x)A' - (3+4x)A = 0. - _Gheorghe Coserea_, Aug 06 2015
a(n) = exp(-1/4)*4^n*Gamma(n+1,-1/4), where Gamma is the incomplete Gamma function. - _Robert Israel_, Aug 07 2015
a(0) = 1; a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n} binomial(n,k) * (4*k - 1) * a(n-k). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Jan 17 2020

A001908.name: E.g.f. exp(-x)/(1-5*x).
formula: E.g.f.: A(x) = exp(-x)/(1-5x) satisfies (1-5x)A' - (4+5x)A = 0. - _Gheorghe Coserea_, Aug 06 2015
a(n) = 5^n*exp(-1/5)*Gamma(n+1,-1/5), where Gamma is the incomplete Gamma function. - _Robert Israel_, Aug 06 2015
a(0) = 1; a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n} binomial(n,k) * (5*k - 1) * a(n-k). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Jan 17 2020

A001909.name: a(n) = n*a(n-1) + (n-4)*a(n-2), a(2) = 0, a(3) = 1.
formula: E.g.f.: exp(-x) / (1 - x)^5 = Sum_{k>=0} a(k+3) * x^k / k!. - _Michael Somos_, Feb 19 2003
a(n) = hypergeom([5,-n+3],[],1))*(-1)^(n+1) for n>=3. - _Peter Luschny_, Sep 20 2014

A001910.name: a(n) = n*a(n-1) + (n-5)*a(n-2).
formula: E.g.f. with offset -1: (exp(-x)/(1-x))*(1-x)^5 = exp(-x)/(1-x)^6. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Jun 02 2010
a(n) = hypergeometric([6,-n+4],[],1)*(-1)^n for n >=4. - _Peter Luschny_, Sep 20 2014

A001911.name: a(n) = Fibonacci(n+3) - 2.
formula: Sum of consecutive pairs of A000071 (partial sums of Fibonacci numbers). - _Paul Barry_, Apr 17 2004
a(n) = A108617(n+1, 2) = A108617(n+1, n-1) for n > 0. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Jun 12 2005
Eigensequence of an infinite lower triangular matrix with the natural numbers as the left border and (1, 0, 1, 0, ...) in all other columns. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Jan 30 2012
a(n) = A000032(6+n)-1 mod A000045(6+n). - _Mario C. Enriquez_, Apr 01 2017

A001912.name: Numbers n such that 4*n^2 + 1 is prime.

A001913.name: Full reptend primes: primes with primitive root 10.

A001914.name: Cyclic numbers: 10 is a quadratic residue modulo p and class of mantissa is 2.

A001915.name: Primes p such that the congruence 2^x == 3 (mod p) is solvable.

A001916.name: Primes p such that the congruence 2^x = 5 (mod p) is solvable.

A001917.name: (p-1)/x, where p = prime(n) and x = ord(2,p), the smallest positive integer such that 2^x == 1 mod p.

A001918.name: Least positive primitive root of n-th prime.

A001919.name: Eighth column of quadrinomial coefficients.
formula: G.f.: (x^3)*(6-8*x+3*x^2 )/(1-x)^8. Numerator polynomial is N4(7, x) from array A063421.
a(n) = 6*C(n,3) + 16*C(n,4) + 15*C(n,5) + 6*C(n,6) + C(n,7) (see comment in A071675). - _Vladimir Shevelev_ and _Peter J. C. Moses_, Jun 22 2012

A001921.name: a(n) = 14*a(n-1) - a(n-2) + 6 for n>1, a(0)=0, a(1)=7.
formula: G.f.: x*(-7 + x)/(x - 1)/(x^2 - 14*x + 1) (see _Simon Plouffe_ in Maple section).
a(n) = -1 - a(-1-n) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Aug 17 2018

A001922.name: Numbers n such that 3*n^2-3*n+1 is both a square (A000290) and a centered hexagonal number (A003215).
formula: G.f.: (1-7*x)/((1-x)*(1-14*x+x^2)). - _Simon Plouffe_ (in his 1992 dissertation) and Colin Barker, Jan 01 2012

A001923.name: a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n} k^k.
formula: a(n+1)/a(n) > e*n and a(n+1)/a(n) is asymptotic to e*n. - _Benoit Cloitre_, Sep 29 2002
For n > 0: a(n) = a(n-1) + A000312(n). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Jul 11 2014

A001924.name: Apply partial sum operator twice to Fibonacci numbers.
formula: Convolution of natural numbers n >= 1 with Fibonacci numbers F(k).
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} Sum_{i=0..k} Fibonacci(i). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Jan 26 2003
F(n) + a(n-3) = A133640(n). - _Gary W. Adamson_, Sep 19 2007
a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n} C(n-k+2,k+1), with n>=0. - _Paolo P. Lava_, Apr 16 2008
INVERT transform is A122595. PSUM transform is A014162. PSUMSIGN transform is A129696. BINOMIAL transform of A039834 with 0,1 prepended is this sequence. - _Michael Somos_, Dec 31 2012
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} Sum_{i=0..n} i * C(n-k,k-i). - _Wesley Ivan Hurt_, Sep 21 2017

A001927.name: Number of connected partially ordered sets with n labeled points.
formula: E.g.f. A(x)=log(B(x)) where B(x) is e.g.f. of A001035.

A001928.name: Number of connected topologies with n unlabeled nodes.
formula: Inverse Euler transform of A001930. - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Jan 06 2006

A001929.name: Number of connected topologies on n labeled points.

A001930.name: Number of topologies, or transitive digraphs with n unlabeled nodes.

A001931.name: Number of fixed 3-dimensional polycubes with n cells; lattice animals in the simple cubic lattice (6 nearest neighbors), face-connected cubes.

A001932.name: Sum of Fibonacci (A000045) and Pell (A000129) numbers.

A001933.name: Chessboard polyominoes with n squares.
formula: For odd n, a(n) = 2*A000105(n). - _John Mason_, Nov 27 2013

M(n) is the number of free polyominoes of size n that have reflectional symmetry on a horizontal or vertical axis that coincides with the edges of some of the squares. (Note for example that the 3 X 3 square nonomino is not included, as the axes of symmetry do not coincide with the edges of any squares.) M(n) = 0 for all n not multiples of 2.

R90(n) is the number of free polyominoes of size n that have 90-degree rotational symmetry about a point that coincides with the corner of a square. Note that for polyominoes which have a hole in the center, the center of rotation will be the corner of a square within the hole, rather than being the corner of a square of the polyomino itself. R90(n) = 0 for all n not multiples of 4. Exclude from R90(n) any polyominoes already in M(n).

R180 (n) is the number of free polyominoes of size n that have 180-degree rotational symmetry about a point that coincides with the mid-side of a square. Note that for polyominoes which have a hole in the center, the center of rotation will be the mid-side of a square within the hole, rather than being within a square of the polyomino itself. R180 (n) = 0 for all n not multiples of 2. Exclude from R180 (n) any polyominoes already in M(n).

A001934.name: Expansion of 1/theta_4(q)^2 in powers of q.
formula: Expansion of eta(q^2)^2/eta(q)^4 in powers of q, where eta(x)=prod(n>=1,1-q^n).
a(n) = (-1)^n * A004403(n). a(n) = 4 * A002318(n) unless n=0. - _Michael Somos_, Feb 24 2011
a(n) ~ exp(Pi*sqrt(2*n)) / (2^(15/4) * n^(5/4)) * (1 - 15/(8*Pi*sqrt(2*n)) + 105/(256*Pi^2*n)). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Aug 17 2015, extended Jan 22 2017
a(0) = 1, a(n) = (4/n)*Sum_{k=1..n} A002131(k)*a(n-k) for n > 0. - _Seiichi Manyama_, May 02 2017

A001935.name: Number of partitions with no even part repeated; partitions of n in which no parts are multiples of 4.
formula: Expansion of q^(-1/8) * eta(q^4) / eta(q) in powers of q. - _Michael Somos_, Mar 19 2004

Expansion of psi(-x) / phi(-x) = psi(x) / phi(-x^2) = psi(x^2) / psi(-x) = chi(x) / chi(-x^2)^2 = 1 / (chi(x) * chi(-x)^2) = 1 / (chi(-x) * chi(-x^2)) = f(-x^4) / f(-x) in powers of x where phi(), psi(), chi(), f() are Ramanujan theta functions. - _Michael Somos_, Jul 08 2011
G.f.: Product(j>=1, 1 + x^j + x^(2*j) + x^(3*j)). - _Jon Perry_, Mar 30 2004
G.f.: Sum_{n>=0} ( x^(n*(n+1)/2) * Product_{k=1..n} (1+x^k)/(1-x^k) ). - _Joerg Arndt_, Apr 07 2011
G.f.: P(x^4)/P(x) where P(x) = Product_{k>=1} 1-x^k. - _Joerg Arndt_, Jun 21 2011
G.f.:  (1+ 1/G(0))/2, where G(k)= 1 - x^(2*k+1) - x^(2*k+1)/(1 + x^(2*k+2) + x^(2*k+2)/G(k+1) ); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jul 03 2013
G.f.: exp( Sum_{n>=1} (x^n/n) / (1 + (-x)^n) ). - _Paul D. Hanna_, Jul 24 2013
G.f. is a period 1 Fourier series which satisfies f(-1 / (256 t)) = 1/2 g(t) where q = exp(2 Pi i t) and g() is the g.f. for A082303. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 30 2017

A001936.name: Expansion of q^(-1/4) * (eta(q^4) / eta(q))^2 in powers of q.
formula: Convolution square of A001935. A079006(n) = (-1)^n a(n).
Expansion of q^(-1/4) * (1/2) * (k / k')^(1/2) in powers of q.
Given g.f. A(x), then B(q) = (q * A(q^4))^4 satisfies 0 = f(B(q), B(q^2)) where f(u, v) = (1 + 16*u) * (1 + 16*v) * v - u^2. - _Michael Somos_, Jul 09 2005
Given g.f. A(x), then B(q) = q * A(q^4) satisfies 0 = f(B(q), B(q^3)) where f(u, v) = (u^2 + v^2)^2 - u*v * (1 + 4*u*v)^2. - _Michael Somos_, Jul 09 2005
Equals A000009 convolved with A098613. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Mar 24 2011
Convolution inverse is A082304. - _Michael Somos_, May 16 2015
G.f. is a period 1 Fourier series which satisfies f(-1 / (64 t)) = (1/4) g(t) where q = exp(2 Pi i t) and g() is the g.f. for A082304. - _Michael Somos_, May 16 2015

Expansion of f(-x^4)^2 / f(-x)^2 = psi(x^2) / phi(-x) = psi(-x)^2 / phi(-x)^2 = psi(x)^2 / phi(-x^2)^2 = psi(x^2)^2 / psi(-x)^2 = chi(x)^2 / chi(-x^2)^4 = 1 / (chi(x)^2 * chi(-x)^4) = 1 / (chi(-x)^2 * chi(-x^2)^2) in powers of q where phi(), psi(), chi(), f() are Ramanujan theta functions. - _Michael Somos_, May 16 2015
G.f.: A(x) = Sum_{n >= 0} x^(n*(n+1)) / Sum_{n = -oo..oo} (-1)^n*x^(n^2). - _Peter Bala_, Feb 19 2021

A001937.name: Expansion of (psi(x^2) / psi(-x))^3 in powers of x where psi() is a Ramanujan theta function.
formula: Expansion of q^(-3/8) * (eta(q^4) / eta(q))^3 in powers of q. - _Michael Somos_, Jul 26 2012
Euler transform of period 4 sequence [ 3, 3, 3, 0, ...]. - _Michael Somos_, Mar 06 2011
Convolution cube of A001935. A187053(n) = (-1)^n * a(n). - _Michael Somos_, Mar 06 2011

A001938.name: Expansion of k/(4*q^(1/2)) in powers of q, where k defined by sqrt(k) = theta_2(0, q))/theta_3(0, q).
formula: Expansion of (psi(x^2) / phi(x))^2 = (psi(x) / phi(x))^4 = (psi(x^2) / psi(x))^4 = (psi(-x) / psi(-x^2))^4 = (chi(-x) / chi(-x^2)^2)^4 = (chi(x)^2 * chi(-x))^-4 = (chi(x) * chi(-x^2))^-4 = (f(-x^4) / f(x))^4 in powers of x where phi(), psi(), chi(), f() are Ramanujan theta functions. - _Michael Somos_, Feb 26 2012
G.f. A(x) satisfies 1 = (1 - 16 * x * A(x)^2) * (1 + 16 * x * A(-x)^2). - _Michael Somos_, Mar 26 2004
Expansion of q^(-1/2) * (eta(q) * eta(q^4)^2 / eta(q^2)^3)^4 in powers of q.
Given g.f. A(x), then B(q) = q * A(q^2) satisfies 0 = f(B(q), B(q^2)) where f(u, v) = v - (u * (1 + 4*v))^2. - _Michael Somos_, Mar 26 2004
G.f. A(q) satisfies A(q) = sqrt(A(q^2)) / (1 + 4*q*A(q^2)); together with limit_{n->infinity} A(x^n) = 1 this gives a fast algorithm to compute the series. [Joerg Arndt, Aug 06 2011]
a(n) = (-1)^n * A093160(n). Convolution square of A079006.
G.f. is a period 1 Fourier series which satisfies f(-1 / (8 t)) = 1/4 g(t) where q = exp(2 Pi i t) and g() is the g.f. for A139820. - _Michael Somos_, Jun 04 2015
G.f.: ((Sum_{n >= 0} x^(n*(n+1))) / (1 + Sum_{n >= 1} x^(n^2)))^4 (from the sum representation of the Jacobi theta functions evaluated at vanishing argument). - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Jul 04 2016

A001939.name: Expansion of (psi(-x) / phi(-x))^5 in powers of x where phi(), psi() are Ramanujan theta functions.
formula: Expansion of q^(-5/8) * (eta(q^4) / eta(q))^5 in powers of q. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 24 2011
Euler transform of period 4 sequence [ 5, 5, 5, 0, ...]. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 24 2011

A001940.name: Absolute value of coefficients of an elliptic function.
formula: G.f.: Product_{k>=1} ((1 + x^(2*k))/(1 - x^(2*k-1)))^6. - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Dec 04 2017

A001941.name: Absolute values of coefficients of an elliptic function.
formula: G.f.: Product_{k>=1} ((1 + x^(2*k))/(1 - x^(2*k-1)))^7. - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Dec 04 2017

A001942.name: Expansion of reciprocal of theta series of Leech lattice.

A001943.name: Expansion of reciprocal of theta series of E_8 lattice.

A001944.name: Numbers that are the sum of 4 distinct squares: of form w^2 + x^2 + y^2 + z^2 with 0 <= w < x < y < z.

A001945.name: a(n+6) = -a(n+5) + a(n+4) + 3a(n+3) + a(n+2) - a(n+1) - a(n). a(n) = sign(n) if abs(n)<=3.
formula: a(n) ~ r1^n-2*real(r2^n), with r1=1.324717957 the inverse real root of x^3+x^2-1=0 and r2=(0.87744+0.7448617i) one inverse complex root of x^3-x-1=0. With n>9, a(n) = round(r1^n-2*real(r2^n)). - _Ralf Stephan_, Dec 17 2002
a(n) = (alpha^n - 1)*(beta^n - 1)*(gamma^n - 1) where alpha, beta and gamma are the zeros of x^3 - x - 1. - _Peter Bala_, Sep 15 2019

A001946.name: a(n) = 11*a(n-1) + a(n-2).
formula: a(n) = Lucas(5n) = Fibonacci(5n-1) + Fibonacci(5n+1). - _Alexander Adamchuk_, Oct 25 2006
a(n) = ( Fibonacci(5*n + 2*k) - F(5*n - 2*k) )/Fibonacci(2*k) for nonzero integer k.
a(n) = ( Fibonacci(5*n + 2*k + 1) + F(5*n - 2*k - 1) )/Fibonacci(2*k + 1) for arbitrary integer k.

A001947.name: a(n) = Lucas(5*n+2).
formula: G.f.: (3 - 4*x) / (1 - 11*x - x^2). - Corrected by _Colin Barker_, Apr 22 2017

A001948.name: These numbers when multiplied by all powers of 4 give the numbers that are not the sums of 4 distinct squares.

A001949.name: Solutions of a fifth-order probability difference equation.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n-4} Sum_{j=0..floor((n-k-4)/5)} (-1)^j*binomial(n-5*j-5, k-1)*binomial(n-k-5*j-4, j). - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Oct 19 2011
a(n) = 1 + a(n-1) + a(n-2) + a(n-3) + a(n-4) + a(n-5) for n >= 5. (See Eq. (4) and the Theorem with r = 5 on p. 356 of Dunkel (1925).)
a(n) = T(n - 5, 5) for n >= 5, where T(n, k) = Sum_{j = 0..floor(n/(k+1))} (-1)^j * binomial(n - k*j, n - (k+1)*j) * 2^(n - (k+1)*j) for 0 <= k <= n. This is _Richard Choulet_'s formula in A172119.

A001950.name: Upper Wythoff sequence (a Beatty sequence): a(n) = floor(n*phi^2), where phi = (1+sqrt(5))/2.
formula: a(n) = n + floor(n*phi). In general, floor(n*phi^m) = Fibonacci(m-1)*n + floor(Fibonacci(m)*n*phi). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Mar 18 2003
a(n) = n + floor(n*phi) = n + A000201(n). - _Paul Weisenhorn_ and _Philippe Deléham_
Append a 0 to the Zeckendorf expansion (cf. A035517) of n-th term of A000201.
a(n) = Min(m: A134409(m) = A006336(n)). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Oct 24 2007

If a'=A000201 is the ordered complement (in N) of {a(n)}, then a(Fib(r-2)+j) = Fib(r)+a(j) for 0<j<=Fib(r-2), 3<r; and a'(Fib(r-1)+j) = Fib(r)+a'(j) for 0<j<=Fib(r-2), 2<r. - _Paul Weisenhorn_, Aug 18 2012
with a(1)=2, a(2)=5, a'(1)=1, a'(2)=3 and 1<k and a(k-1)<n<=a(k) one gets a(n)=3*n-k, a'(n)=2*n-k. - _Paul Weisenhorn_, Aug 21 2012

A001952.name: A Beatty sequence: a(n) = floor(n*(2 + sqrt(2))).

A001954.name: Wythoff game.
formula: a(n + 1) - a(n) is either 3 or 4. Note the comment regarding some intervals in the complement (A001953). - _Ralf Steiner_, Oct 27 2019

A001957.name: Wythoff game.
formula: a(n) = floor( (n+1/3) * (sqrt(13)-1) /2). - R. J. Mathar, Feb 14 2011

A001958.name: Wythoff game.
formula: a(n) = floor( (n+1/3) * (5+sqrt(13)) /2). - R. J. Mathar, Feb 14 2011

A001959.name: Wythoff game.
formula: a(n) = floor( (n+2/3)*(sqrt(13)-1)/2 ). - R. J. Mathar, Feb 14 2011

A001960.name: Wythoff game.
formula: a(n) = floor((n+2/3)*(5+sqrt 13)/2) . - R. J. Mathar, Feb 14 2011

A001963.name: Wythoff game.
formula: a(n) = floor( (n+1/4)*(sqrt(5)-1) ). - R. J. Mathar, Feb 14 2011

A001964.name: Wythoff game.
formula: a(n) = floor( (n+1/4)*(3+sqrt(5)) ). - R. J. Mathar, Feb 14 2011

A001965.name: Wythoff game.
formula: a(n) = floor( (n+1/2)*(sqrt(5)-1) ). - R. J. Mathar, Feb 14 2011

A001967.name: Wythoff game.
formula: a(n) = floor( (n+3/4)*(sqrt(5)-1) ). - R. J. Mathar, Feb 14 2011

A001968.name: Wythoff game.
formula: a(n) = floor( (n+3/4)*(3+sqrt 5) ) . - R. J. Mathar, Feb 14 2011

A001969.name: Evil numbers: nonnegative integers with an even number of 1's in their binary expansion.
formula: Note that 2n+1 is in the sequence iff 2n is not and so this sequence has asymptotic density 1/2. - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Aug 23 2006
G.f.: Sum_{k>=0} (t(3+2t+3t^2)/(1-t^2)^2) * Product_{l=0..k-1} (1-x^(2^l)), where t = x^2^k. - _Ralf Stephan_, Mar 25 2004
n such that A010060(n-1)=0. - _Benoit Cloitre_, Nov 15 2003
a(2*n) - a(2*n-1) gives the Thue-Morse sequence (3, 1 version): 3, 1, 1, 3, 1, 3, 3, 1, 1, 3, .... A001969(n) + A000069(n) = A016813(n-1) = 4*n-3. - _Philippe Deléham_, Feb 04 2004
a(1) = 0; for n > 1: a(n) = 3*n-3 - a(n/2) if n even, a(n) = a((n+1)/2)+n-1 if n odd.
Let b(n) = 1 if sum of digits of n is even, -1 if it is odd; then Shallit (1985) showed that Product_{n>=0} ((2n+1)/(2n+2))^b(n) = 1/sqrt(2).

A001970.name: Functional determinants; partitions of partitions; Euler transform applied twice to all 1's sequence.
formula: G.f.: Product_{k >= 1} 1/(1-x^k)^p(k), where p(k) = number of partitions of k = A000041. [Cayley]
a(n) = (1/n)*Sum_{k = 1..n} a(n-k)*b(k), n > 1, a(0) = 1, b(k) = Sum_{d|k} d*numbpart(d), where numbpart(d) = number of partitions of d, cf. A061259. - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Apr 21 2001
Logarithmic derivative yields A061259 (equivalent to above formula from Vladeta Jovovic). - _Paul D. Hanna_, Sep 05 2012
a(n) = Sum_{k=1..A000041(n)} A001055(A215366(n,k)) = number of factorizations of Heinz numbers of integer partitions of n. - _Gus Wiseman_, Dec 19 2016

a(n) = |{m>=1 : n = Sum_{k=1..A001222(m)} A056239(A112798(m,k)+1)}| = number of normalized twice-prime-factored multiset partitions (see A275024) whose total sum of parts is n. - _Gus Wiseman_, Dec 19 2016

A001971.name: Nearest integer to n^2/8.
formula: The listed terms through a(20)=50 satisfy a(n+2) = a(n-2) + n. - _John W. Layman_, Dec 16 1999
Euler transform of length 6 sequence [ 1, 1, 1, 1, 0, -1]. - _Michael Somos_, Aug 29 2015
a(n) = a(-n) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Aug 29 2015

A001972.name: Expansion of 1/((1-x)^2*(1-x^4)) = 1/( (1+x)*(1+x^2)*(1-x)^3 ).
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} floor((k+4)/4) = n + 1 + Sum_{k=0..n} floor(k/4). - _Paul Barry_, Aug 19 2003
a(n) = a(-6-n) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Mar 13 2020

A001973.name: Expansion of (1+x^3)/((1-x)*(1-x^2)^2*(1-x^3)).
formula: a(n) is the coefficient of x^(2*n+2) in the g.f. Product_{s=1..4} (x^s - x^(n+1))/(1-x^s). - _Paul Weisenhorn_, Jun 01 2009
a(n) = 2*a(n-1) - a(n-3) - a(n-4) + 2*a(n-6) - a(n-7). _Vincenzo Librandi_, Jun 11 2012

A001974.name: Numbers that are the sum of 3 distinct squares, i.e., numbers of the form x^2 + y^2 + z^2 with 0 <= x < y < z.

A001975.name: Number of partitions of floor(5n/2) into n nonnegative integers each no more than 5.
formula: Coefficient of x^w*z^n in the expansion of 1/((1-z)(1-xz)(1-x^2z)(1-x^3z)(1-x^4z)(1-x^5z)), where w=floor(5n/2). - Herman Jamke (hermanjamke(AT)fastmail.fm), Feb 17 2008

A001976.name: Number of partitions of floor(5n/2)-1 into n nonnegative integers each no more than 5.
formula: Coefficient of x^w*z^n in the expansion of 1/((1-z)(1-xz)(1-x^2z)(1-x^3z)(1-x^4z)(1-x^5z)), where w=floor(5n/2)-1. - Herman Jamke (hermanjamke(AT)fastmail.fm), Feb 17 2008

A001977.name: Number of partitions of 3n into n parts from the set {0, 1,.., 6} (repetitions admissible).
formula: a(n) is the coefficient of x^(3*n+3) from the G.f. product[s=1..6] (x^s-x^(n+1))/(1-x^s). - _Paul Weisenhorn_, Jun 01 2009

A001978.name: Number of partitions of 3n-1 into n nonnegative integers each no more than 6.
formula: Coefficient of x^w*z^n in the expansion of 1/((1-z)(1-xz)(1-x^2z)(1-x^3z)(1-x^4z)(1-x^5z)(1-x^6z)), where w=3n-1. - Herman Jamke (hermanjamke(AT)fastmail.fm), Feb 17 2008

A001979.name: Number of partitions of floor(7n/2) into n nonnegative integers each no more than 7.
formula: Coefficient of x^w*z^n in the expansion of 1/((1-z)(1-xz)(1-x^2z)(1-x^3z)(1-x^4z)(1-x^5z)(1-x^6z)(1-x^7z)), where w=floor(7n/2). - Herman Jamke (hermanjamke(AT)fastmail.fm), Feb 17 2008

A001980.name: Number of partitions of floor(7n/2)-1 into n nonnegative integers each no greater than 7.
formula: Coefficient of x^w*z^n in the expansion of 1/((1-z)(1-xz)(1-x^2z)(1-x^3z)(1-x^4z)(1-x^5z)(1-x^6z)(1-x^7z)), where w=floor(7n/2)-1. - Herman Jamke (hermanjamke(AT)fastmail.fm), Feb 17 2008

A001982.name: Number of partitions of 4n-1 into n nonnegative integers each no greater than 8.
formula: Coefficient of x^w*z^n in the expansion of 1/((1-z)(1-xz)(1-x^2z)(1-x^3z)(1-x^4z)(1-x^5z)(1-x^6z)(1-x^7z)(1-x^8z)), where w=4n-1. - Herman Jamke (hermanjamke(AT)fastmail.fm), Feb 17 2008

A001983.name: Numbers that are the sum of 2 distinct squares: of form x^2 + y^2 with 0 <= x < y.

A001986.name: Let p be the n-th odd prime. Then a(n) is the least prime congruent to 3 modulo 8 such that Legendre(-a(n), q) = -1 for all odd primes q <= p.

A001987.name: Class numbers associated with entries of A001986.

A001988.name: Let p be the n-th odd prime. a(n) is the least prime congruent to 7 modulo 8 such that Legendre(-a(n), q) = -Legendre(-1, q) for all odd primes q <= p.

A001989.name: Class numbers associated with entries of A001988.

A001990.name: Let p be the n-th odd prime. a(n) is the least prime congruent to 5 modulo 8 such that Legendre(-a(n), q) = -Legendre(-2, q) for all odd primes q <= p.

A001991.name: Class numbers associated with entries of A001990.

A001992.name: Let p = n-th odd prime. Then a(n) = least prime congruent to 5 modulo 8 such that Legendre(a(n), q) = -1 for all odd primes q <= p.

A001993.name: Number of two-rowed partitions of length 3.

A001995.name: Numbers that are the sum of 5 distinct squares: of form v^2 + w^2 + x^2 + y^2 + z^2 with 0 <= v < w < x < y < z.

A001996.name: Number of partitions of n into parts 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7.
formula: Euler transform of length 7 sequence [ 0, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1]. - _Michael Somos_, Apr 23 2014

A001997.name: Number of different shapes formed by bending a piece of wire of length n in the plane.

A001998.name: Bending a piece of wire of length n+1; walks of length n+1 on a tetrahedron; also non-branched catafusenes with n+2 condensed hexagons.
formula: a(n-1) = Sum_{j=1..k} (S2(n,j) + Ach(n,j)) / 2, where k=3 is the maximum number of colors, S2 is the Stirling subset number A008277, and Ach(n,k) = [n>=0 & n<2 & n==k] + [n>1]*(k*Ach(n-2,k) + Ach(n-2,k-1) + Ach(n-2,k-2)).

A001999.name: a(n) = a(n-1)*(a(n-1)^2 - 3).
formula: a(n) = 2*F(2*3^n+1) - F(2*3^n) = ceiling(tau^(2*3^n)) where F(k) = A000045(k) is the k-th Fibonacci number and tau is the golden ratio. - _Benoit Cloitre_, Nov 29 2002
a(n) = 2*T(3^n,3/2), where T(n,x) denotes the n-th Chebyshev polynomial of the first kind. Cf. A219161. - _Peter Bala_, Feb 01 2017

A002000.name: a(n+1) = a(n)*(a(n)^2 - 3) with a(0) = 7.
formula: a(n) = 2*T(3^n,7/2), where T(n,x) denotes the n-th Chebyshev polynomial of the first kind.
